lead_paragraph: Michelin, the European tire maker, generated 575 million euros ($912 million) of cash in the first half as the company cut production more rapidly than sales declined. While Michelin had a net loss of 119 million euros in the period, the company reported an operating profit of 282 million euros on sales of more expensive tires. Operating profit excludes some one-time items. Revenue fell 13 percent to 7.13 billion euros, with a shift in demand to more expensive tire brands and models helping limit the slide, the company said.

lead_paragraph: IN 2009, communications spending is likely to show a 1 percent decline for the year, the first notable decline in at least four decades. In five years, advertising spending in magazines will finally have rebounded after five years of decline  but at $9.8 billion, it will still be nowhere near the $12.9 billion it was in 2008. And by 2013, the video game market will be almost the size of the shrinking newspaper industry.

abstract: The real estate mogul has managed to get his Atlantic City casinos out of bankruptcy for a third time. Equity firms could take lessons.

lead_paragraph: Donald Trump’s latest resurrection isn’t necessarily a bellwether for other buyouts. The casino mogul turned reality television star has persuaded a bank to restructure a loan to allow his Atlantic City casinos to emerge from bankruptcy  again. While that sounds like an encouraging return of risky lending, it doesn’t necessarily mean financing will flow for private equity firms seeking to fix their own problem companies.

The Office of Advocacy of the Small Business Administration shows that small businesses, which they define as any business with fewer than 500 employees, account for 99.7 percent of all employer firms in this country. That’s such a large percentage of businesses that referring to small businesses as a single group obscures important differences among them.

abstract: IDC said that spending on online display advertising dropped 12 percent, while classified ads lost 17 percent. Search advertising rose slightly in the second quarter.
snippet: IDC said that spending on online display advertising dropped 12 percent, while classified ads lost 17 percent. Search advertising rose slightly in the second quarter.
lead_paragraph: Here’s a quick update on the once-invincible business known as online advertising. Worldwide spending on Internet advertising shrank by 5 percent in the second quarter of the year, to $13.9 billion from $14.7 billion, according to research firm IDC. That is the second consecutive quarter that revenues have dropped over the previous year’s quarter, which is creating all sorts of pressure on firms like Yahoo, AOL and the wide world of ad-dependent Web start-ups.

headline.main: Internet Ad Spending Shrinks Again

abstract: Fewer people are losing their jobs, but the number of long-term unemployed workers keeps rising.
snippet: Fewer people are losing their jobs, but the number of long-term unemployed workers keeps rising.
lead_paragraph: There are clear signs that world economy is turning up, or at least not sinking further, but today’s jobs report is not a bright spot. The unemployment rate went down, from 9.5 percent to 9.4 percent, but that is statistically unimportant given the sampling error in the household survey. In any case, it fell not because more people said they had jobs — employment was down in that survey — but because fewer people were still looking for work.

headline.main: Not as Bad, but Not Good

abstract: The Target Corporation plans to run its own Web site starting in 2011, ending a 10-year deal under with Amazon.com.
snippet: The Target Corporation plans to run its own Web site starting in 2011, ending a 10-year deal under with Amazon.com.
lead_paragraph: The Target Corporation plans to run its own Web site starting in 2011, ending a 10-year deal under which Amazon.com fills the site’s orders and provides customer support. Target, the second-largest discount retailer in the United States, after Wal-Mart, will take over building and managing Target.com before the 2011 holiday season, the company said in a statement on Friday. Amazon, the world’s largest online retailer, agreed in 2001 to provide customer care, technology and order fulfillment for Target.com to help the discount retailer lower costs and improve customer service. “We’ve had a very positive, productive relationship with Amazon,” Kelly Basgen, a Target spokeswoman, said. However, she added, “We just thought it was in our best interest to grow and manage our own platform.” Target said it would work with Amazon until the contract expired.

headline.main: Target to End Deal With Amazon to Run Its Web Site
headline.print_headline: Target to End Deal With Amazon to Run Its Web Site

abstract: The General Motors Company, which is majority owned by the United States Treasury, intends to make an initial public offering of stock by July 10, 2010
snippet: The General Motors Company, which is majority owned by the United States Treasury, intends to make an initial public offering of stock by July 10, 2010
lead_paragraph: The General Motors Company, the new automaker majority-owned by the United States Treasury, said Friday that it intended to make an initial public offering of stock by July 10, 2010, the one-year anniversary of its exit from bankruptcy. The target date range for an offering was disclosed Friday in a federal regulatory filing that the company said summarized its activities in the four weeks since it left court protection. G.M. said it was authorized to issue 2.5 billion shares of common stock. G.M. will begin releasing financial data after the third quarter, a spokeswoman, Renee Rashid-Merem, said. The company’s filing did not include financial results. “Today’s disclosures are consistent with our commitment to remain transparent and to keep the public informed of our progress,” the chief executive, Fritz Henderson, above, said in a statement.

headline.main: General Motors Is Planning to Hold an I.P.O. Next July
headline.print_headline: General Motors Is Planning To Hold An I.P.O. Next July

abstract: Three former sales representatives with Hewlett-Packard are suing the company, claiming that they were denied tens of thousands of dollars in commissions.
snippet: Three former sales representatives with Hewlett-Packard are suing the company, claiming that they were denied tens of thousands of dollars in commissions.
lead_paragraph: Three former sales representatives with Hewlett-Packard are suing the company, claiming that they were denied tens of thousands of dollars in commissions because of a malfunction in an order-management system. As many as 50,000 current and former sales representatives have not received commissions and bonuses because of problems with the software system that tracks sales, called Omega, according to a lawsuit filed this week in federal court in San Francisco. Hewlett-Packard said Wednesday that about 2,000 members of its global sales team of 23,000 were affected by the Omega glitch. The company was working to fix the problem, Gina Giamanco, a spokeswoman, said then.

headline.main: Former Sales Representatives Sue Hewlett-Packard
headline.print_headline: Former Sales Representatives Sue Hewlett-Packard

abstract: First State Bank and Community National Bank, both based in Sarasota, Fla., were closed on Friday, pushing the number of failed United States lenders to 71 this year.
snippet: First State Bank and Community National Bank, both based in Sarasota, Fla., were closed on Friday, pushing the number of failed United States lenders to 71 this year.
lead_paragraph: First State Bank and Community National Bank, both based in Sarasota, Fla., were closed on Friday, pushing the number of failed American lenders to 71 this year. The Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation was named receiver for both banks. Closing the lenders, with combined assets of $560 million and deposits of $480 million, will cost the deposit insurance fund about $140 million. Stearns Bank of St. Cloud, Minn., will assume all deposits, the agency said.

headline.main: F.D.I.C. Closes Two Failed Banks Based in Florida

abstract: Colonial BancGroup confirmed it was the target of a federal criminal investigation, dealing a blow to its struggle to survive.
snippet: Colonial BancGroup confirmed it was the target of a federal criminal investigation, dealing a blow to its struggle to survive.
lead_paragraph: Colonial BancGroup confirmed it was the target of a federal criminal investigation, dealing a blow to its struggle to survive. The bank, which recently acknowledged it might not be able to continue as a going concern, said the Justice Department was investigating its lending division that originates mortgages the bank does not intend to keep, as well as related accounting irregularities over several years. Colonial, based in Montgomery, Ala., said it received subpoenas from the Securities and Exchange Commission related to the capital it set aside for soured loans and its effort to participate in the Troubled Asset Relief Program. The bank also said the Alabama State Banking Board would meet on Wednesday and ask it to consent to be taken into receivership by the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, should such action be deemed necessary. If Colonial does not survive, it would be the fifth-largest bank failure in United States history. Colonial has 355 branches in five states and about $25 billion in assets.

headline.main: Colonial BancGroup Says It Is Focus of U.S. Inquiry
headline.print_headline: Colonial BancGroup Says It Is Focus of U.S. Inquiry

lead_paragraph: SHENZHEN, China  In this sprawling metropolis in southeastern China stand two hulking brown buildings erected by a private company, the Longgang trash incinerators. They can be smelled a mile away and pour out so much dark smoke and hazardous chemicals that hundreds of local residents recently staged an all-day sit-in, demanding that the incinerators be cleaner and that a planned third incinerator not be built nearby.

abstract: Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada and President Ricardo Martinelli of Panama signed a free trade agreement, continuing Canada’s efforts to bolster investment and trade in the region

lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Stephen Harper of Canada and President Ricardo Martinelli of Panama, left, signed a free trade agreement, continuing Canada’s efforts to bolster investment and trade in the region after talks at the Doha round of World Trade Organization negotiations stalled. The agreement will remove tariffs on 90 percent of goods imported from Canada, with those remaining to be phased out over the next decade, Mr. Harper’s office said. Canada exported $128 million Canadian dollars ($118 million) of goods like meat, forest products and flight simulators to Panama in 2008, up 48 percent from 2007, the office said.

lead_paragraph: I wonder what the folks who work on the molecular (as opposed to digital) version of The New York Times think about 1 Across. Newspapers used to make money on classified ads and now that entire revenue stream is gone. The problem with trying to sell information in the Internet age is that no matter how little you want to charge for it, someone else is willing to undercut your price or even provide a free alternative for their own broader business reasons. Try selling crossword answers for $1.49 a minute when bloggers reveal all for the price of a mouse click. How this will all shake out is anyone’s guess. We live in interesting times.

With his white beard, he looks a little like Santa Claus, only more distinguished. He is 66 years old.

lead_paragraph: That would be Judge Jed Rakoff and Judge Richard Sullivan, both of whom this week said no to the government. Judge Rakoff refused to sign off on consent decree that the S.E.C. negotiated with Bank of America regarding its lack of disclosure about those now-infamous Merrill Lynch bonuses. His prodding is likely to force Bank of America to tell the country more about the issues surrounding the bonuses than any of the three loud but generally pointless Congressional hearings.

headline.main: A Tale of Two Judges

abstract: Rambus, the designer of computer chips for consumer electronics, won a court ruling allowing the company to continue pursuing its antitrust claims against memory-chip manufacturers.
snippet: Rambus, the designer of computer chips for consumer electronics, won a court ruling allowing the company to continue pursuing its antitrust claims against memory-chip manufacturers.
lead_paragraph: Rambus, the designer of computer chips for games and other consumer electronics, won a court ruling allowing the company to continue pursuing its antitrust claims against memory-chip manufacturers. A California appeals court denied a request on Thursday by Micron Technology to block some claims from going forward. Shares of Rambus rose $1.94, or 12.3 percent, to $17.75 on Friday. Micron’s request that the appeals court reconsider rulings made by Judge Richard A. Kramer in San Francisco, and set aside the judge’s denial of Micron’s bid to dismiss the case, was the last such attempt by the manufacturers, said Jeff Schreiner, an analyst at CapStone Investments, based in San Diego. “There’s nothing left before Judge Kramer that could stop the trial at this point,” Mr. Schreiner said. The trial is to start Sept. 28.

headline.main: Antitrust Lawsuit by Rambus Advances
headline.print_headline: Antitrust Lawsuit By Rambus Advances

lead_paragraph: In an Unboxed column in Sunday’s newspaper, I look at the continuing role and competitive advantage, if any, of large corporate research labs, given the new models of open innovation in the Internet era. abstract: Old Spice is pushing the notion “Residue Is Evil,” with bizarre ads to persuade men to use its new Ever Clear deodorant line.
snippet: Old Spice is pushing the notion “Residue Is Evil,” with bizarre ads to persuade men to use its new Ever Clear deodorant line.
lead_paragraph: IN a print ad for Ever Clear, a new men’s antiperspirant from Old Spice, a male in his 20s stands on a beach. Waving and smiling, he is clearly unaware that, dangling from his underarm to nearly his knee, is the word “idiot,” spelled out in white, foamy letters, which match bits of deodorant visible in his armpit. A bikini-clad woman looks up from a magazine at him, and the copy reads, “Residue Is Evil. Stop It.”

lead_paragraph: China’s $200 billion sovereign wealth fund, which has suffered big losses on paper on stakes in Morgan Stanley and the Blackstone Group, is set to invest up to $2 billion in United States mortgages as it anticipates a property market recovery, Reuters reported Monday, citing two people with direct knowledge of the matter.

headline.main: China’s Fund Said to Plan U.S. Mortgage Investments

abstract: The numbers seem to be improving for those who work for themselves.
snippet: The numbers seem to be improving for those who work for themselves.
lead_paragraph: Back in January, when I was still blogging at U.S. News and World Report, I wrote a post that showed that, even though the number of self-employed people initially rose at the beginning of the recession, by the end of 2008, the rate of job loss was more severe among the self-employed than among those in the private sector who work for others. By December 2008, the number of self-employed people was only 96.2 percent of what it was before the recession began, while the number of private sector wage employed people was 97.2 percent of the December 2007 level.

headline.main: Job Loss Abating Among the Self-Employed

abstract: Everyblock.com is being bought.
snippet: Everyblock.com is being bought.
lead_paragraph: Brad Stone from our sister site Bits reports that EveryBlock.com, the two year-old experiment in hyperlocal news, is being bought by MSNBC.com, a joint venture between NBC and Microsoft. EveryBlock.com, a start-up based in Chicago, has been working to publish data feeds from governments in 15 American cities, including San Francisco, New York and Atlanta, and has been seen as a model for local coverage with information like police reports, building permits and restaurant inspections.

abstract: New research has shown that tightwads and spendthrifts tend to marry, and then fight over finances. But are they fighting about spending in general, or spending priorities?
snippet: New research has shown that tightwads and spendthrifts tend to marry, and then fight over finances. But are they fighting about spending in general, or spending priorities?
lead_paragraph: In yesterday’s Week in Review, I delved more deeply into a working paper about how “spendthrifts” and “tightwads” tend to marry each other. (The study flies in the face of most psychological research, which finds that birds of a feather usually flock together, sometimes in weird ways.) This turns out to be an unfortunate attraction, since such dichotomous couples report more marital conflict.

headline.main: What Are We Fighting Over When We Fight Over Money?

abstract: The writer Alain de Botton will produce a book in September about his one-week appointment as the airport’s writer in residence.
snippet: The writer Alain de Botton will produce a book in September about his one-week appointment as the airport’s writer in residence.
lead_paragraph: TRAVELERS passing through London's Heathrow Airport this week may be surprised to encounter, in the middle of its bustling Terminal 5, the writer Alain de Botton, author of popular books including “How Proust Can Change Your Life” and “The Art of Travel,” seated at a desk and tapping away at his laptop computer. His typing appears in real time on a screen behind him, and a placard explains  in what apparently is both a literary and aeronautic first  that Mr. de Botton is serving a one-week appointment as Heathrow’s “writer in residence.”

headline.main: Waiting at Heathrow, the Literary Experience

abstract: Entrepreneurs tend to like people and to be optimistic, which is dangerous in the hiring process. Here’s a better approach: Think guilty until proven innocent.
snippet: Entrepreneurs tend to like people and to be optimistic, which is dangerous in the hiring process. Here’s a better approach: Think guilty until proven innocent.
lead_paragraph: There are some signs that the economy is starting to turn around. If you have been running lean on people, you might be considering hiring someone soon. Happily, there are some very good people out there looking for jobs — but there are many more less-than-good people. The question is, how do you know which is which? You can get lucky only so often. I can tell you that most of the business problems I’ve had over the years have been because of bad hiring.

headline.main: Updating the Peter Principle: How to Hire After the Recession

abstract: If you don’t have time to supervise your children on the Internet, your home-network router may be able to do it for you.
snippet: If you don’t have time to supervise your children on the Internet, your home-network router may be able to do it for you.
lead_paragraph: If you don’t have time to supervise your children on the Internet, your home-network router may be able to do it for you. Many models (especially newer ones from Netgear, Cisco and Linksys) include parental control features in the router’s settings. If your router comes with these options, you can probably set up use limits and block access to the Internet at certain times of the day. And if the youngsters claim they need Internet access for homework, check your router for settings that filter out certain types of Web sites  not only the usual adult-oriented Web servers, but social networking and video-sharing sites as well. Check your router’s manual for its specific features and instructions for changing the settings.

headline.main: Tip of the Week: Parental Controls for the Internet

lead_paragraph: The world’s savviest hackers are on to the “real-time Web” and using it to devilish effect. The real-time Web is the fire hose of information coming from services like Twitter. The latest generation of Trojans — nasty little programs that hacking gangs use to burrow onto your computer — sends a Twitter-like stream of updates about everything you do back to their controllers, many of whom, researchers say, are in Eastern Europe. Trojans used to just accumulate secret diaries of your Web surfing and periodically sent the results on to the hacker.

headline.main: How Hackers Snatch Real-Time Security ID Numbers

abstract: The retailer of women’s business attire reported a 21 percent decline in revenue in the second quarter and forecast continued pressure on sales this year.
snippet: The retailer of women’s business attire reported a 21 percent decline in revenue in the second quarter and forecast continued pressure on sales this year.
lead_paragraph: AnnTaylor Stores, the retailer of women’s business attire, reported a 21 percent decline in revenue in the second quarter and forecast continued pressure on sales this year. Sales at locations open at least one year declined 22.5 percent, the company said. Comparable-store sales at Ann Taylor stores fell 38 percent, while those at Loft fell 15.4 percent. Profit excluding restructuring costs was 6 cents a share, the company said. Analysts estimated 3 cents. The net loss was $18 million, or 32 cents a share, contrasted with a profit of $29.3 million, or 50 cents, a year earlier. Sales in the period, which ended Aug. 1, fell to $470 million from $592 million.

headline.main: AnnTaylor Posts Decline in Revenue
headline.print_headline: AnnTaylor Posts Decline In Revenue

abstract: In a press release the S.B.A. brings the good news about small business contracting. Not surprisingly, the whole story is more complicated and less complimentary to the bureaucracy.
snippet: In a press release the S.B.A. brings the good news about small business contracting. Not surprisingly, the whole story is more complicated and less complimentary to the bureaucracy.
lead_paragraph: The Small Business Administration took a victory lap Friday in the press release (pdf) that accompanied its annual scorecard rating the government on awarding contracts to small firms. In fiscal year 2008, which ended last Sept. 30, “small businesses won a record $93.3 billion in federal prime contracts,” the agency said, “an increase of almost $10 billion from 2007.” Moreover, “small disadvantaged businesses, women-owned businesses and service-disabled veteran-owned businesses increased their share of federal contracting dollars by at least $1 billion to $3 billion.”

headline.main: The S.B.A. Puts the Best Face on Small-Business Contracting

abstract: The world’s savviest hackers are on to the “real-time Web” and using it to devilish effect.

lead_paragraph: The world’s savviest hackers are on to the “real-time Web” and using it to devilish effect. The real-time Web is the fire hose of information coming from services like Twitter. The latest generation of Trojans  nasty little programs that hacking gangs use to burrow onto your computer  sends a Twitter-like stream of updates about everything you do back to their controllers, many of whom, researchers say, are in Eastern Europe.

headline.main: Hackers Exploit an Evolving Web

abstract: The nomination of Ben S. Bernanke to a second term as Fed chairman was greeted with praise on Capitol Hill, but there are still lawmakers on the left and the right who wonder whether Mr. Bernanke is the right person for the job.

abstract: Aging residents of nursing home for former stars and other Hollywood workers are told it’s closing by year’s end.
snippet: Aging residents of nursing home for former stars and other Hollywood workers are told it’s closing by year’s end.
lead_paragraph: Fasten your seatbelts, it’s going to be a bumpy ride. The Motion Picture and Television Fund on Tuesday began notifying the 78 or so residents in its long-term care unit and hospital in California’s San Fernando Valley that the facility — where generations of aging actors, directors, craftspeople and others lived the final years of their lives — is definitely closing by year’s end.

headline.main: Residents of Nursing Home for Hollywood Workers Are Told It’s Closing

headline.print_headline: Scrutiny for S.E.C. In Merrill Bonuses

Instead, they keep their friends on both sites informed by setting up Twitter to automatically post tweets on Facebook, and they never have to visit the site.

abstract: A look at whether the National Federation of Independent Business has partisan leanings.
snippet: A look at whether the National Federation of Independent Business has partisan leanings.
lead_paragraph: A few weeks back, You’re The Boss readers rose up in mild insurrection against The Agenda. The occasion was a look at the Small Business Majority, a liberal organization trying to influence the health care debate. Readers thought The Agenda was unfair. “Subject the other business organizations to the same analysis and you would find AT LEAST as much ideology and partisan bias as the author has found on the Small Business Majority,” wrote one critic. Citing the National Federation of Independent Business, she added, “A few years ago, the N.F.I.B. contributed 95% of its PAC money to Republican candidates.” Another offered: “The N.F.I.B. on any piece of legislation will be slanted towards the leanings [of] the paying membership and, thus, not representative the feelings of all small businessmen.”

headline.main: Whom Does the N.F.I.B. Represent (Besides Its Members)?

Anheuser-Busch InBev — purveyor of the president’s preferred brew, Bud Light — and MillerCoors, a joint venture between SABMiller and Molson Coors, are raising prices at the same time, during a recession and while beer demand is slumping.
